title: Photography
text:
As a wizard and scholar of Middle-earth, I have been studying the magic of the natural world for centuries. Through my self-portraits, I aim to capture the essence of my own being and reflect on my own journey through time. Each photograph is a reflection of my own experiences and emotions. Through my photography, I hope to offer a glimpse into my life as a scholar and adventurer, and inspire others to reflect on their own journeys through the world.



















View the tutorial for this template (+ download link)

title: Research
text: I am most interested in clinical trial design, and specifically in applications to health disparities. My current research work is in intervention trials. I am pursuing my PhD with the hope of creating more diverse clinical trials and increasing representation for underserved communities. My long-term goal is to become a professor and teach classes in public health and/or statistics.

title: Projects
text:
arXiv Preprint | Code
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

title: Projects
section: The History of the War of the Ring
text:
The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth’s history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

title: Welcome to my website!
text:
LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Welcome to my website!
I am Olivia Lindberg, a student in the Epidemiology and Biostatistics PhD program at Case Western Reserve University. The program is within the Department of Population and Quantitative Health Sciences in the School of Medicine. I graduated from Penn State University in 2024 (We are!) with my B.S. in Biostatistics. I love numbers and working with health data!
On this website, you’ll find in depth information about my research experiences as well as my interests and goals. Please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects.

title: Research
text: I am most interested in clinical trial design, and specifically in applications to health disparities. My current research work is in intervention trials. I am pursuing my PhD with the hope of creating more diverse clinical trials and increasing representation for underserved communities. My long-term goal is to become a professor and teach classes in public health and/or statistics.

title: Blog
text:
In one of my courses this semester, we’re reading a book called “How To Be A Modern Scientist” by Jeff Leek. One really useful chapter was about scientific blogging, which is something I don’t think about too often. Blogging seems like it’s been left behind with the rise of LinkedIn and X as professional and scientific communication platforms. However, Leek highlights the importance of maintaining a scientific blog, along with many other practices that are beneficial as a scientist. Especially being early in my career (first-year into my PhD) I really appreciate how Leek explained the value of exposure and connection by blogging. I’m hopeful to make many connections in my field, and starting a blog could be a good way to get more connected to the greater biostats community. Also, for personal use, I think it would be nice to have blog posts to look back on later in my career. It’s cool that I’m still at the start of my journey in biostats, and I’m sure this will be an interesting time to look back on. Also, blogging could be especially useful to document my struggles and hurdles in completing my thesis. I’m not sure if anyone will end up reading this but I think there’s enough good reason to start a blog regardless of potential audience or exposure.
To set the stage, I’m currently in my second semester of my first year at CWRU. It’s been a very busy, exhausting, and overwhelming year, but I’m so grateful to be here. It feels like all of my hard work in high school and undergrad is finally paying off with real progress towards my goals. During my most challenging days, I always remind myself how lucky I am to be here. Education is a privilege, especially now more than ever, and being a grad student is one of the coolest jobs. I get to learn and grow and explore my interests. It’s also an excuse to not be a real adult with a 9-5 for a few more years.
